moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nd4 4. Bc4 e6: From this position Black could secure a slight advantage with 8...Nxe4 9.O-O d5 (as in Petrov-Pucher, Le Touquet, 2006), which is why White would have been better advised to play 8.d3.
moves.8... Bc5 9. Nb3 Bxf2+:
[?!]
The quieter 9.… Bd6 10.d4 Nxe4 is preferable, but the text definitely gets White's attention, just not enough of it.
moves.10. Kxf2 Nxe4+ 11. Ke3:
[?]
Oblivious to his danger White neglects to address Black’s threat of getting his queen into play with check.  11.Kf1 seems best; granted it locks in his h-rook, but up a bishop and ahead in development White can surely find the extra tempi to get that rook out of hock.
moves.11... b5 12. Bxb5:
[?]
Black gave White a reprieve – 11.… d5 12.Bf1
    • (12.Bd3 Qg5+ 13.Ke2 Qxg2+ 14.Ke1 Qf2#)
    • (12.Be2 Qg5+ 13.Kd3 Nf2+ wins the queen)
    • (12.Qf3 Ng5 wins the bishop)
12.… Qg5+ 13.Ke2 e5 14.h3 Ng3+ wins the exchange – but White panics and so does not see that substituting 12.Be2 for 12.Bxb5? and proceeding as in the actual game salvages a draw as in the note following Black's 17th move.
moves.12... Qg5+ 13. Kxe4 Bb7+ 14. Kd3 Qf5+ 15: Black passes on the chance for a draw by repetition with 17.… Qe4+ 18.Kf2 Qg2+ 19.Ke3 (19.Ke1? Qxh1+ 20.Bf1 Qxh2 gives Black a rook and two pawns for a bishop and a knight) Qe4+ etc.
